title: Individual investors go bargain hunting amid growing signs of recession, E-Trade data show
text:
Defensive sectors have taken a decisive leadership role in recent weeks, but individual investors are looking to buck market trends, buying up shares of companies in more cyclical sectors like materials, consumer discretionary and financials, according to data from E-Trade Financial.

Investors on the platform appear to “believe there will be no trade resolution before the election, and while the stock selloff isn’t bad enough to drive investors totally into defensive sectors, they’re too nervous to go all in on tech,” said Chris Larkin, senior vice president of trading at E-Trade Financial Corp ETFC, -1.75%.

During August, rising trade barriers, verbal volleys between Washington and Beijing leaders and a recession signals in the bond market have helped to spark the second monthly decline for stocks in 2019, with the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.69% falling 1.8%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -1.08% losing 1.7% and the Nasdaq Composite Index retreating 2.6% COMP, -1.11%.

Over the same period, defensive sectors including utilities, consumer staples and real estate were the only three of 11 with positive gains. Defensive sectors are so named because stocks in those categories tend to collectively outperform during periods of market turbulence. Utilities shares gained 4.1%, consumer staples 2.3% and real estate 4.6%, in August, according to FactSet.

E-Trade clients, however, bucked this trend and were net sellers of real estate and consumer staples stocks, though they were net buyers of utilities.

E-Trrade Financial Corp.

Larkin said that these flows are evidence of individual investors looking for quality stocks on the cheap in cyclical sectors that have lagged behind the market this year. “We’re seeing pronounced interest in middle-ground players like materials,” he said. He pointed to Freeport-McMoRan Inc. FCX, -1.31% as one company in the sector that clients are buying and “which has been down significantly and could be viewed as a bargain.”

The Materials Select Sector SPDR fund XLB, -0.79% has appreciated 11.1% year-to-date, versus the S&P 500’s 15.7% rise.

Though the information technology sector remains the second-best performing year-to-date, E-Trade clients were net sellers of these stocks in August, driven by concerns over global trade. Clients have been sellers of semiconductor stocks in particular, including Advanced Micro Devices Inc. AMD, -1.75%, Symantec Corp. SYMC, -1.12% and Cisco Systems Inc. CSCO, -0.66%.

“Chip makers have been a trade war casualty,” Larkin said. “And we’re seeing traders unload some of their positions in some of the well-known players.”
